contentrichtext.text: {{Taxobox | name = Marbled Godwit | status = LC | status_system = IUCN3.1 | status_ref = <ref>{{IUCN|id=106003006 |title=''Limosa fedoa'' |assessors=[[BirdLife International]] |version=2012.1 |year=2012 |accessdate=16 July 2012}}</ref> | image = MarbledGodwit.jpg | regnum = [[Animal]]ia | phylum = [[Chordate|Chordata]] | classis = [[bird|Aves]] | ordo = [[Charadriiformes]] | familia = [[Scolopacidae]] | genus = ''[[Godwit|Limosa]]'' | species = '''''L. fedoa''''' | binomial = ''Limosa fedoa'' | binomial_authority = ([[Carolus Linnaeus|Linnaeus]], 1758) | range_map = Limosa_fedoa_map.svg }} The '''Marbled Godwit''' (''Limosa fedoa'') is a large [[shorebird]]. On average, it is the largest of the 4 species of [[godwit]]. The total length is {{convert|40|-|50|cm|in|abbr=on}}, including a large bill of {{convert|8|-|13|cm|in|abbr=on}}, and wingspan is {{convert|70|-|88|cm|in|abbr=on}}.<ref>[http://www.dnr.state.mn.us/rsg/profile.html?action=elementDetail&selectedElement=ABNNF08040] (2011).</ref> Body mass can vary from {{convert|240|to|510|g|oz|abbr=on}}.<ref name = "CRC">''CRC Handbook of Avian Body Masses'' by John B. Dunning Jr. (Editor). CRC Press (1992), ISBN 978-0-8493-4258-5.</ref> Adults have long blue-grey hairy legs and a very long pink bill with a slight upward curve and dark at the tip. The long neck, breast and belly are pale brown with dark bars on the breast and flanks. The back is mottled and dark. They show cinnamon wing linings in flight. Their breeding habitat is the northern prairies of western [[Canada]]-([[Canadian Prairies]]), and the north central [[Great Plains]], [[United States]] near marshes or ponds. They nest on the ground, usually in short grass. In autumn, they [[bird migration|migrate]] in flocks to the coasts of [[California]], the [[Gulf of Mexico]], [[Mexico]] and [[South America]]. These birds forage by probing on mudflats, in [[marsh]]es, or at the beach (see picture below). In short [[grass]], they may pick up [[insect]]s by sight. They mainly eat insects and [[crustacean]]s, but also eat parts of aquatic plants. Their numbers were reduced by hunting at the end of the 19th century. Although they had recovered somewhat since that time, their population has declined in recent times as suitable habitat is used for farming. <gallery> Image:Marbled Godwit Northern California.jpg|Feeding on mudflat at low tide, [[Elkhorn Slough]] Image:MarbledGodwitsFeeding.jpg|Marbled Godwits feeding, [[Point Reyes National Seashore]], California Image:Marbled godwit Sandiego.jpg|Marbled Godwit landing [[San Diego]] [[California|CA]] Image:Limosa fedoa flight.jpg|In flight File:7Z1E8737.jpg|Flock </gallery> ==References==<!-- RevBrasOrnitol14:465 --> == References == <references /> ==External links== {{wikispecies|Limosa fedoa}} {{commons}} * [http://www.birds.cornell.edu/AllAboutBirds/BirdGuide/Marbled_Godwit.html Marbled Godwit Species Accounty] - Cornell Lab of Ornithology * [http://www.mbr-pwrc.usgs.gov/id/framlst/i2490id.html Marbled Godwit ''Limosa fedoa''] - USGS Patuxent Bird Identification InfoCenter *[http://ibc.hbw.com/ibc/phtml/especie.phtml?idEspecie=1514 Marbled Godwit videos] on the Internet Bird Collection *[http://vireo.acnatsci.org/search.html?Form=Search&SEARCHBY=Common&KEYWORDS=marbled+godwit&showwhat=images&AGE=All&SEX=All&ACT=All&Search=Search&VIEW=All&ORIENTATION=All&RESULTS=24 Marbled Godwit photo gallery] - VIREO <!--combine RangeMaps with the good RangeMap/maps, lists, etc for SOUTH and CENTRAL America at: "www.natureserve.org"(then 'InfoNatura')...the categories shown on the rangemap for the species is: "Passage Migrant", VAGRANT, Breeding Resident, and "Non-Breeding Resident"(mostly on coastlines)(shows only coastlines since the map is small for the two continents)--> [[Category:Shorebirds]] [[Category:Limosa]] [[Category:Native birds of the Canadian Prairies|Godwit, Marbled]] [[Category:Birds of Mexico|Godwit, Marbled]] [[Category:Birds of Central America|Godwit, Marbled]] [[Category:Birds of South America|Godwit, Marbled]] [[Category:Migratory birds (Western hemisphere)|Godwit, Marbled]] [[Category:Native birds of the Plains-Midwest (United States)]]
